text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

NITIN NOHRIA: One of the
most extraordinary things

I have learned in my time as
dean at Harvard Business School

is just how engaged our
alumni are all over the world.

We need a world which is
cleaner, safer, healthier where

more people see
opportunity, where

more people feel confident
in their institutions.

These are all things in
which change is necessary.

KASH RANGAN: To make the
social change happen,

we can't wave our
hands and say, oh,

that is the government's
responsibility.

That's civil
society's responding.

No, it's everybody's
responsibility.

MATT SEGNERI: 25 years
ago, when SEI started,

the mission was to think broader
than just impacting nonprofits.

It was to think about
all of social enterprise.

Regardless of tax status
or organizational or form,

how do we think about creating
high impact social change?

LAURA MOON: As we celebrate
the 25th anniversary

of the social
enterprise initiative,

it gives us an opportunity to
pause and step back and reflect

upon the ways in which we've
had an impact in the world

far beyond the boundaries
of Harvard Business School.

MONIQUE BURNS THOMPSON:
When we ensure

that people have the basic
skills that they need

to be able to be strategic,
how to lead change,

how to lead people,
we're setting ourselves

up for solving all kinds
of problems in the world.

SHANNAH VARON: At Boston
Collegiate Charter School,

we focus every
day on our mission

to prepare each
student for college.

And we're really proud
that 100% of our graduates

have been accepted to
four year colleges.

And we're very focused on making
sure that they're prepared

and they can be
successful adults

and have an impact in
their lives beyond college.

One of the things I love
about being an HBS alum

is there's a group
of eight of us

who are part of a
professional circle,

and we talk about
personal challenges,
professional challenges.
And it's exciting.

And being part of thinking
differently and innovating

and trying things
out in a new way,

that is what the social
enterprise initiative at HBS
does.

It connects all the people who
are doing this kind of work who

have a vision of what the
future can and should be.

The notion that you should
expand your sphere of influence

and have an impact beyond
that which is immediately

in front of you I think
is actually really

part of the ethos of the
social enterprise initiative.

NITIN NOHRIA: The social
enterprise initiative

was first founded
with the simple idea

that John Whitehead had
that if you could find a way

to give these amazing
people who were running

these social enterprises
a little bit of management

education, maybe they could take
their passions so much farther.

Not only can we be
a force for change,

but working with other
social enterprise initiatives

and other business schools
all around the world,

that collective energy can be an
even greater force for change.

JOHN MCARTHUR: The market we
serve as a world is really
a global enterprise.

And we draw students and
faculty and resources
from all around the world.

AZEEZ GUPTA: Before Harvard,
I was working at a nonprofit,

and they were working on
education for the really
underprivileged.

And mostly, these kids were
kids who were dropping out
at the high school level.

50% of kids in
grade five in India

can't even read or
do basic subtraction.

As I worked more and
more, I felt the need

to come to a place where
I could get some more

global exposure in education and
social enterprise more broadly.

The networks that
Harvard has opened up

for me in terms of alumni,
in term of peers, in terms
the faculty--

Harvard has allowed
me to hold the key
to building these coalitions.

And only through that
can you actually solve
these large problems.

CHRIS OSGOOD: I think it's
the Harvard Business School's

great credit that they are
striving to change the world.

The social enterprise
initiative has been
integral for me being here.

I would not be working
for the city of Boston

if it were not for the
leadership fellows program.

The leadership fellows
program is a fantastic way

to connect interested
folks who are

graduating from HBS with
careers in the social sector.

It is opening up a connection
which otherwise would not

have been available
to folks like me

to see how really powerful,
impactful organizations can run

and can deliver even better
for their constituencies.

I have the great
pleasure of working

on a team that
thinks about the nine

square miles of Boston that
are our streets and sidewalks.

We think about our
streets as ways

of moving people through
them, making sure

that people move safely and
well and across the entire city
of Boston.

And I think of the challenges
that Boston is facing right now

and the opportunities
that Boston

is facing right
now, massive growth,

significant opportunities
to increase equality,

real challenges
from climate change,
all those things require change.

And that means
that you constantly

have to be figuring out, what is
that change that the residents

most want, and how
do you as a city,

how do you as a group
of public servants
actually deliver on that?

That can help us build a
better city in the future.

It's a place that people
come together and solve

their biggest challenges and
push towards their highest
aspirations.

KASH RANGAN: Ultimately,
impact is all about what

my students, my
graduate students,

and what my executive education
students go out and do
in the real world.

We as faculty members don't go
out and create that enterprise.

What we can do here as
an education institution
is to influence that.

MAX HODGES: I have a hope
that my story will inspire

lots of other people to come
bring their talents to the art
world.

The arts have been important
to me since I was a kid.

And it was a really big turning
point for me in my career

when I realized I could bring
my skill set to this field
that I am so passionate about.

I love to help build
audiences for the arts,

help broaden access to the
arts and arts education.

HBS and the social
enterprise initiative

encourage students and alum
to follow their true path.

The resources that
are on campus,

the resources for
alumni, all of this

make it possible to
pursue successfully
a career in the nonprofit world.

DUTCH LEONARD:
Social enterprises

throughout the world
performing magnificently

against really
difficult problems--
how does that happen?
How is that possible?

It's possible because the
people and the organizations
are mission-driven.

Their heart and soul is that
they care about these problems

because they want
to know about how

to advance their mission-driven
organizations more
successfully.

MONIQUE BURNS THOMPSON: It is my
hope that our current graduates

will find work that
allows them to create

a solution, a
vision, a strategy,

and they get to
implement it in a way

that they are truly
able to add value.

AZEEZ GUPTA: Hearing from my
peers about the challenges

they faced and,
importantly, the solutions

they've managed to find really
motivates and energizes me

because it shows me that
I can also find solutions
to the challenges that face me.

I aspire to develop an
education system in India that

works for kids who as of now
lack access to basic schooling

and lack access to confidence
that they can have a better

life to be able to make their
way into this world, which
is really rapidly changing.

JOHN MCARTHUR: It
takes an extra amount

of courage for a young
person to walk into something

they've never done
surrounded by people that
don't think they should do it.

We have to keep bringing
in new things that

mostly aren't strongly
supported at the beginning.

KASH RANGAN: The problem and
the challenges might be big.

It doesn't matter whether
you're for profit or nonprofit.

You can bring management
techniques, ideas, analytics
to impact change.

You have 25,000 ambassadors
out there creating change
on a daily basis.

They have all been
influenced by what

happens here in this environment
and take all year to add value
for society.
